text:
in .htaccess:

#  Error document handling:

ErrorDocument   401     /error.php?error=401
ErrorDocument   403     /error.php?error=403
ErrorDocument   404     /error.php?error=404

#  Content protection:

AuthUserFile /home/mordeth/public_html/access/.passwd
AuthGroupFile /dev/null
AuthName "Protected Area"
AuthType Basic

<Limit GET POST>
  require user  mordeth
</Limit>

will return the 401 error page without prompting for a username and password.

if the 3 ErrorDocument lines are added to httpd.conf instead of to the .htaccess
file, the server 403s the 401 page, despite the fact that it is able to read it.

very bizarre.

that .htaccess works perfectly under Apache 1.3.26, by the way.

it took me a long time to figure out that it was the ErrorDocument directives
that were causing a couple of my domains to not ask for username and password.
creator: mordeth@pankurokku.com

text:
This is almost certainly a PHP problem, since the default install includes
some SSI-generated error documents that work just fine.  Most likely, the
reponse status code is getting lost someplace in the PHP filter.  Please
ask on the PHP users mailing list, and if they don't have a solution,
report it in the PHP bug database.

Also, having <Limit GET POST> and </Limit> lines is unnecessary and possibly
a security risk.
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
How can it possibly be a PHP problem that the Apache server does not prompt for
a username and password before serving an ErrorDocument?
creator: mordeth@pankurokku.com

text:
Apache NEVER prompts for a username/password.  It is the browser that
is responsible for that.  And the browser will do it whenever it receives
a 403 HTTP status code from the server.  This status code is sent
WITH the error document, not "before" it.

For more information on HTTP Basic authentication, I suggest you consult
the HTTP specification.

The evidence is:

- Without PHP, apache sends the proper status code (even when using other
filters like mod_include).
- With PHP, apache does not send the proper status code.

That evidence makes it quite likely (though certainly not positive) that the
problem is in the PHP filter.
creator: slive@apache.org
